content:
Hello! Learning Rust (and software design/engineering in general) and enjoying the experience, so far!

I know Rust is a relatively new language, and so learning materials are a bit sparse... but does anyone have any recommendations for books on software design that are either Rust-focused, or easily adapted to Rust?

Thanks!
Hello! Dunno if you've seen this yet: https://www.rust-lang.org/learn
There's also "The Rust Programming Language" as a book. Other books on Rust don't have many reviews in my region, so I didn't get them yet.

@Hameer Abbasi : yea, I'm aware of those resources, and in fact have worked about 2/3 through The Rust Programming Language! Kinda looking for higher-level software design conceptual learning, which I guess is language-agnostic... but if there is something that exists that's implemented in Rust, that'd be cool!
@Poliorcetics : never seen that before! I think I'll run through it. Looks nice!
There is a GitHub about « data oriented design » if you want higher level things. To my knowledge it doesn’t talk about rust at all but it’s interesting nonetheless :smile:
@Poliorcetics : yea, I was recently turned on to that idea! Didn't know there was a GitHub account/repo dedicated to that. I'll def check it out. Thanks!

There's "Programming Rust: Fast, Safe Systems Development" by Blandy and Orendorff. That one seems to have a lot of good reviews.

Doesn't cover third party libraries though.
There's also "Hands-On Data Structures and Algorithms with Rust" by Matzinger. Haven't read that one, since it's Packt, and I've heard things about them that aren't... Good.

@Hameer Abbasi : I actually bought the video lessons for that book on Udemy! I've only gotten to his lectures on sorting algorithms... but, he kinda speeds through the explanations. I often have to re-watch sections a few times before I grasp what he's trying to explain.
As far as I am aware of, The Rust Book is still is still the best resource to get started.
